abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Puttalam Housing Project
            (PHP) for Sri Lanka were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory; and the
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: implementation arrangements. The
            implementation arrangements with a field-based project unit
            in Puttalam helped to address the needs of the Internally
            Displaced Persons (IDPs) in Puttalam in a timely manner.
            However, the project demonstrated that effective
            implementation through this model requires a well
            capacitated project unit coupled with effective coordination
            at the center. Planning for integrated investments, housing,
            water, sanitation, and roads relate closely to each other
            and thus, any interventions that provide these services in a
            package require integrated planning covering technical
            design aspects, staffing, and sequencing of implementation.
            Owner-driven construction, this ICR recognizes the
            challenges that were faced by the home-owners in undertaking
            housing construction as per schedule, but the experience
            seemed to have been appreciated by the owners. The provision
            of cash grants ensured beneficiary participation in the
            construction of their houses, facilitated choice in design
            and use of construction materials, and reduced the cost of
            construction. Technical officers supervised construction
            while a technical audit independently monitored compliance
            with engineering standards. Job training program/skills
            development is one of the important activities of the PHP
            was to create required construction skills among the
            Puttalam IDPs. The skills training program was designed to
            meet the demand for skilled and semi-skilled masons and
            carpenters in project areas. Community involvement in water
            supply investments is one of the institutional mechanisms
            for social integration that worked well under the project
            was the formation of Community Based Organization (CBOs) for
            managing water supply schemes.

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Puttalam Housing Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Puttalam Housing Project for Sri Lanka is to support the
            integration of Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in
            Puttalam by providing housing, drinking water, and
            sanitation facilities to both IDPs and a limited number of
            select non-IDPs in host communities, and rehabilitate
            selected internal roads in the IDP Welfare centers. The
            closing date for the project will be extended from June 30,
            2011 until December 30, 2011.  The extension is necessary to
            give the project more time to implement the activities under
            implementation and achieve the development objectives. The
            project is a multi-sector and complex project and is being
            implemented in difficult environment.  The project has
            already achieved visible and sizable results on the ground.
            For the remaining activities under implementation, in
            particular important infrastructure component (water,
            sanitation, roads) and also the balance housing under
            construction, there is a commitment of close to US$5
            million. The Government of Sri Lanka has formally requested
            IDA for a closing date extension of 6 months to December 30,
            2011.  This will be the first extension of the project.

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Puttalam Housing Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper introduces the
            following changes in the Sri Lanka Puttalam Housing Project.
            The changes are as follows: the provision of housing will be
            expanded from the originally planned permanent housing to
            selected Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) in the refugee
            camps to a limited number of poorest non-IDP households in
            adjacent communities across four divisions in Puttalam
            district. This change is intended to facilitate improvement
            of social cohesion within communities served under the
            project by addressing the housing needs of a group of the
            poorest non-IDP households. This will promote the
            integration of the IDPs into host communities. The basis for
            selection of IDP beneficiaries for a housing cash grant will
            be expanded beyond the list of original eligible
            beneficiaries identified by the United Nations High
            Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) 2006 survey. After the
            project approval, the Government pointed out that the UNHCR
            2006 survey had omitted those IDP households who in fact had
            a temporary house but were classified as those without a
            temporary house and, therefore, had been omitted from the
            list. The Government found, through surveys and an
            Independent Housing Damage Assessment (IHDA), that a number
            of deserving families met the selection criteria and that
            the proportion of the temporary houses and semi-built houses
            is slightly different from that surveyed by the UNHCR 2006
            survey. The Ministry of Resettlement requested IDA to
            consider these beneficiaries under the project and to accept
            the Ministry's survey as a complementary tool to the
            UNHCR 2006 survey for verification of beneficiaries eligible
            for housing grant.
